results.title: McConnell Freezes Up a Second Time While Addressing Reporters
results.abstract: The episode, which took place in the Republican leader’s home state of Kentucky, intensified questions about his future in the Senate.

results.adx_keywords: Personal Finances;Credit and Debt;Women and Girls;Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder
results.title: For Women With Money Issues, an A.D.H.D. Diagnosis Can Be Revelatory
results.abstract: A diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder in adulthood has solved a mystery for some women, helping them get control over their finances.

media.caption: After racking up $15,000 in debt, Ellyce Fulmore was diagnosed with A.D.H.D. in December 2020.
media.copyright: Todd Korol for The New York Times

results.byline: By Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. Rashbaum
results.title: Trump, Under Oath, Says He Averted ‘Nuclear Holocaust’
results.abstract: During a deposition in his civil case, the former president offered a series of defenses, digressions and meandering explanations of his political and professional dealings.
des_facet: New York State Civil Case Against Trump (452564/2022)

media.caption: The civil fraud case against former President Donald Trump and his company is scheduled to head to trial in early October.

results.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Jonathan Weisman
results.title: Is Trump Disqualified? Republicans Prepare to Fight Long-Shot Legal Theory.
results.abstract: In New Hampshire, Republicans are feuding over whether the 14th Amendment bars Donald J. Trump from running for president. Other states are watching closely.

media.caption: Bryant Messner, a former Republican candidate for Senate in New Hampshire, wants the courts to weigh in quickly on whether the 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution disqualifies Donald J. Trump from appearing on the ballot next year.
media.copyright: John Tully for The New York Times

results.title: How Trump’s Election Lies Left the Michigan G.O.P. Broken and Battered
results.abstract: Infighting between Trump acolytes and traditionalists has driven away donors and voters. Can the Michigan Republican Party rebuild in time for the presidential election?

media.caption: Kristina Karamo pledged to bring in a new donor class when she was named chair of the Michigan Republican Party, but it never materialized.
media.copyright: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times

results.byline: By Nicholas Nehamas and Maya King
results.title: After Jacksonville, Tensions Flare Between DeSantis and Black Floridians
results.abstract: At a vigil for the shooting victims, Mr. DeSantis had to speak over loud boos from a largely Black crowd. His agenda in Florida has earned him few Black allies.

media.caption: Gov. Ron DeSantis’s conservative policies have angered the African American community in Florida, particularly one regarding how slavery is taught in schools.
media.copyright: Malcolm Jackson for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Area Planning and Renewal;Urban Areas;Patrick Bernard;Paris (France)
results.title: Parisians Are Pledging Allegiance to the ‘Republic of Super Neighbors.’ They Must Bring Cheese.
results.abstract: A grass-roots movement aims to recast urban living in Paris and other cities around the world through a hyperlocal prism of neighborliness.

media.caption: Patrick Bernard, the founder of the Republic of Super Neighbors in Paris, center background, with participants in the 14th arrondissement. He encourages neighbors who interact five times daily to do so 50 times a day.
media.copyright: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

results.title: Republican Women, Fearing Backlash on Abortion, Pivot to Birth Control
results.abstract: A group of politically vulnerable G.O.P. women has backed legislation that purports to expand birth control access but would have little effect. Critics say the bill is meant to distract from their anti-abortion stances.

media.caption: Representative Mariannette Miller-Meeks, Republican of Iowa, has spent part of the summer congressional recess talking up her support for birth control access to constituents.

results.title: Hitting Theater Hard: The Loss of Subscribers Who Went to Everything
results.abstract: The subscription model, in which theatergoers buy a season’s worth of shows at a time, had long been waning, but it fell off a cliff during the pandemic.

media.caption: At the Clarence Brown Theater in Knoxville, Tenn., Kyle Hooks, left, and George Hairston assemble the front of a train car for “Murder on the Orient Express,” which the theater is hoping will attract audiences.

results.abstract: Afghanistan has always been at the mercy of would-be liberators.

results.title: Tina Howe, Playwright Best Known for ‘Coastal Disturbances,’ Dies at 85
results.abstract: She mixed insight and absurdity in a vast body of work that also included “Painting Churches” and “Pride’s Crossing,” both of which were Pulitzer finalists.

media.caption: Tina Howe in 2009. She was known for writing plays that presented multidimensional female characters of a type not often seen when she started out in the 1970s.

results.title: Emulating Trump, Ramaswamy Shows a Penchant for Dispensing With the Facts
results.abstract: In clashes with the news media and his rivals, the Republican upstart has retreated from past comments and lied about on-the-record statements.
